Description: Roman letters
Greek letters (see [this](https://www.overleaf.com/learn/latex/List_of_Greek_letters_and_math_symbols) for all possible letters)

Letters will automatically be italicized and treated as math variables;
if you want actual text in the math, use `\text{}`
Extra spaces will automatically be removed; if you want a space, use `\Â `
Use `^` to make one character superscripted.
Wrap the superscripted part in `{}` if there's more than one character
Use `_` to make one character subscripted
Wrap the subscripted part in `{}` if there's more than one character
Use superscripts and subscripts simultaneously
You can even nest them
Addition
Subtraction
Multiplication
Division
Fractions
Square roots; use `[3]` for other roots
Summation; use sub/superscripts for extra details
Products; use sub/superscripts for extra details
Integrals; use sub/superscripts for extra details
Add a bar for things like averages
Use an overline for longer things
Add a hat for things like estimates
Use a wide hat for longer things
Use arrows for DAG-like things

Use colors!; see [here](https://www.overleaf.com/learn/latex/Using_colours_in_LaTeX) for more details and [here](https://www.overleaf.com/learn/latex/Using_colours_in_LaTeX#Reference_guide) for a list of color names
